results.title: Bird Watcher's Hide
results.brief_description: A young boy is introduced to bird watching by an experienced watcher. On the Scottish moors he learns how to select a bird, find the nest, construct the hide and patiently move it closer without disturbing the bird, until he is able to view intimately the bird’s habits. No other credits available.

results.title: Bird sanctuary
results.brief_description: The hatching and rearing of young seabirds in the Farne Islands off the coast of Britain. Such well-known birds as the kittiwakes, the guillemots, the cormorants, the puffins, the terns, the elderducks and the lesser known black-backed gulls are observed.

results.title: Bird safari in Australia
results.creator_credit: David Cook, Laszlo Erdos and Jenny Erdos
results.brief_description: Filmed entirely on location in the Mallee type country of Southern Australia, this film explores the paradise that is shared by birds, plants and insects in their natural environment. Features wonderful close-ups of undisturbed wildlife while the background music is a beautiful symphony of bird songs and calls. Narrated by Fred Parslow.

results.title: Bird of the thunder woman
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and David Parer
results.brief_description: An analysis of a wealth exchange cycle in the Papua New Guinea Highlands. Shows part of the Sa cycle of the Wola people of Halalinja, Southern Highlands Province. Cassowaries and pigs, which are highly prized, are raised by the women. At a ceremony lasting two days the birds and pigs are slaughtered by the men and the meat is distributed to relatives and friends. This ceremony is just one in an elaborate cycle of gift exchanges. English commentary, Papua New Guinea dialogue with English subtitles. Narrated by Robyn Williams.

results.title: Bird banding in Australia
results.creator_credit: CSIRO, Division of Wildlife Research and S.T. Evans
results.brief_description: Shows how the handling of birds helps biologists to collect information essential for the study and conservation of rare species and the control of pests. Some of the diverse methods banders use for trapping wild birds are shown.

results.title: Biquefarre
results.creator_credit: Midas, Millia Films, William Gilcher, Marie-Francoise Mascaro, Bertrand van Effenterre and Georges Rouquier
results.brief_description: The title of Georges Rouquier’s final film is the name of a small farm in Aveyron, France and the narrative revolves around the changing nature of farming life there. Within this setting a middle-aged farmer decides to sell up and move to Toulouse, a decision that leads to two neighbours competing to buy, with an array of underhanded methods undertaken to secure the deal. The background to these shenanigans is the daily life and routine of farm life, highlighting the escalating mechanisation, automation of practice and procedures and difficulties inherent within the economics of land ownership, expensive machinery and unstable returns. This naturalistic film works as a companion piece to “Farrebique” (1945); in fact it can almost be read as a sequel to Rouquier’s earlier work in which the same family were carefully considering the introduction of electricity. Using a cast of non-professional actors, and engaging a documentary feel, Rouquier successfully evokes the milieu of rural life, presenting it here in a non-idealised manner, an aesthetic contrast to the evocative bucolic mise-en-scene of “Farrebique”. Cast includes Henri Rouquier, Maria Rouquier, Roger Malet, Marius Benaben and Helene Benaben.

results.title: Biquefarre
results.creator_credit: Bertrand van Effenterre, Marie-Francoise Mascaro, William Gilcher and Georges Rouquier
results.brief_description:
Georges Rouquier revisits the characters of his 1938 ‘Biquefarre’ 35 year later. The family whose farm was wired for electricity in the first film are still on the family spread in 1983. The plot revolves around Raoul who decides to sell the farm to take up a job as gardener with the City of Toulouse. Though documentary in technique, the film is well planned and scripted, with its amateur cast convincingly mouthing the lines given them by Rouqier.

Credits: Producer, Bertrand van Effenterre, Marie-Francoise Mascaro, William Gilcher ; director, Georges Rouquier ; writers, Georges Rouquier, Maria Signorini ; photography, Andre Villard ; music, Yves Gilbert
Cast: Henri Rouquier, Maria Rouquier, Roger Malet, Roch Rouquier, Raymond Rouquier.

results.title: Bionics: man or machine
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Alan P. Sloan
results.brief_description: Presents a brief history of bionics, the science of copying nature. Examines some of the successful machines that have been created as a result of bionic research, and investigates some possibilities for the future. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Bioncle: mask of light
results.creator_credit: The Lego Group, Miramax Films, Sue Shakespeare, David Molina and Terry Shakespeare
results.brief_description: CGI animated feature about robot creatures called Bionicles who live by a code of Unity, Duty and Destiny. ‘Chronicle’ finds a hidden mask that is the mask of light - he must take this mask to find his destiny which is to be the 7th Toa. A good versus evil battle evolves as light battles with the dark Master of Shadow in a bid to free the island home of Mata Nui from darkness. Made by the Lego Company and sure to be enjoyed by young purchasers of BionicleTM products. Direction and Art Direction by David Molina and Terry Shakespeare with a screenplay by Henry Gilroy.

results.title: Biomagnetism
results.creator_credit: Reel Images, SBS-TV, Brian Beaton and Celia Tait
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Nature of healing”.
This program looks at magnetic field therapy, an approach much researched, particularly in Japan. Biomagnetic therapy combined with drug therapy has been used to successfully treat depression, dementia, non-healing fractures and spinal injuries.
